content.description: An unfortunately typical Smoke Bluffs bolted slab. The holds are excruciatingly small and polished. This climb feels really hard for the grade, even admitting that a slab 11a should have very small holds. It's likely that the edges have lost a bit of their bite over time, as appears to have happened on a number of Smoke Bluffs slabs (Dreams of Passion at Ronin's Corner and especially Tools of Moss Destruction at Fern Gully). Nevertheless, all of the moves are doable and a top-rope session can serve as an early-season tune-up for your slab technique. This is face just right of Davey Jones' Locker. There are two bolts before the first ledge, one before the next ledge and then one more on the finishing arete of Diddly Squat. There is a two-bolt anchor shared with Diddly Squat at the top but the anchor lacks rappel rings or quicklinks for lowering.

This worthwhile route has languished in obscurity having been climbed but not named and then treated as an italicized footnote in Squamish Rockclimbs. Definitely a proud line by Smoke Bluffs standards I have taken the liberty of naming it in the hopes of bringing it into the light.

Starts on the classic Wonderland and then quickly break right up a finger crack that dissipates into tech crystal crimping. A couple of sloping chickenheads offer brief reprieve between cruxes. Exhilarating final moves with good exposure! 



Located between Wonderland and White Rabbit. This route is hard to see from the ledge below. For those who prefer to top rope inspect the anchor is pretty easy to find by walking past Joe's Crack top out.

A few cams from .3 -.75 protect the initial crack and then 3 bolts protect the crux slab. Stainless lower off rings installed courtesy of the Squamish Access Society.

The crux is getting on this very popular, very easy route.  It takes pretty good gear, though, and it's easy to walk up and set up a TR, so it's worthwhile to bring beginners or first-time leaders here.

The Locker is in the back of the left-most dihedral, just to the right of Joes Crack.
Cams, nuts, or hexes to 2 inches.  Bolts at the top, no chains. Walk off the back towards the stairs and around to the base.

This climb starts hard right off the ground and consists of cranking up a flaring seam that provides no good locks or feet.  The wall steep and the crack angles awkwardly.  At about halfway, you pull around the arete to the left and continue on the type of bulging slab that characterizes so many routes at the Smoke Bluffs.  The grade drops to low 5.10 once you're on the arete.

The is the obvious seam on the face left of the route Pixie Corner.
I didn't lead it so take this with a grain of salt, but small stoppers and micro cams are likely necessary near the bottom.  I believe that some bolts appear as the seam dies out and you move over to the arete.

The strikingly thin pin scarred diagonal crack by the entrance of Pixies Corner.

Entrance of Pixies Corner
4 bolts

Don't be fooled by Pixie Corner's chill routes, because Joe's is pretty stout for a 5.9. It can be tricky to place gear in the left to right angling crack, and the top out is very committing. Joe's feels harder, or at least more awkward, than Penny Lane. Joe's Crack is on the right facing wall of the farthest-left dihedral in Pixie Corner. It angles from left to right, then goes straight up into the trees. You can't miss it.
Walk up and right to top of cliff, and follow path to stairs and the base of the dihedrals. Cams to 2 inches. Two bolts with quicklinks at the top for lowering.

Climb directy up the blunt arete to the left of Digital Dexterity staying out of the broken diagonal that lead out towards digital dexterity.

Entrance of Pixes Corner directly to the left of Digital Dexterity.
One bolt, and TCU's.

The "title" crack in Pixie Corner is the best of the lot, offering a fun, well protected climb up two thin parallel cracks in the back of a huge dihedral. This is a fun introduction to Squamish's unique brand of slimy finger cracks, smearing, and jamming. This is the unmistakable "ski tracks" route in Pixie Corner, and the first to be encountered when entering the area.

Walk off the back, per every other climb on this cliff. Cams to 1.5 inches, med. nuts. There are anchors with chains at the top.

A short but enjoyable route that follows the obvious, diagonal crack to the right of pixie corner. The crux comes at the last move and requires good foot placement to reach to a decently positive but slopey final hold.

This is the left-slanting crack immediately to the right of the large dihedral crack system. Scamper up a low ledge to access the crack. Walk off the back as for other routes in this area.
standard nuts and cams to 1.5" or Easily toproped via backside approach. Single anchor bolt and a conveniently positioned tree at the top.

Two parallel cracks on rounded buttress left of Joes Crack.  Start off a ledge.

Standard rack.

I found the Crux to be near the top portion of the arete feature with some tricky moves to work through. Really nice climb and well worth doing again. Would make for a really scary and dangerous lead as it only has 2 bolts protecting the whole 60ft. climb.

This climb is found on the arete between Captain Hornblower 5.11a and Diddly Squat 5.12b which climbs the blank face just right of Weiner in the Bun. You can walk off or be lowered or rap off if you want. most people walk off right to the stair case leading back down to pixie corner crag.
Only two bolts protect the entire route. May be areas to place removable protection but take a good look before leading it. I say it simply needs more bolts to make it safe. Two bolts at the top for your anchor

A low thin finger layback crux leads to a pumpy crack to anchors. 
 This route seems like a logical extension of Jabberwocky.

standard rack to 1"

climbs.name: Wonderland
climbs.fa: R. Barley, P. Shakleton, C. Murrell

content.description:
This is a wild and exposed line that traverses above the height of the wall area.  Begin on a ledge left of the Jabberwocky anchor, and hand traverse a finger/hand crack up and left across the void.  Pull up onto a bulge and move left through stellar moves on a series of flakes.  Traverse around the corner as the crack widens, then climb a short section of fist crack to the anchor.  Savor the view.  A unique and highly worthwhile pitch.

Walk left from the Pixie corner area, or arrive at the base while doing the Smoke Bluff Connection.
Gear to 3-4", primarily finger and hand size pieces.  I had two #3 camalots and was pleased to have them near the end of the pitch.

Pixie Corner sits in the trees above the Neat and Cool cliffs, and is a perfect place to bring beginners or a small group of friends.  The area hosts a dozen or so one pitch routes, ranging from classic Squamish 5.7 to 5.9 cracks to the one of the sickest, thinnest lines in Squamish (Digital Dexterity, 12c). 
  
 The main attractions are Wonderland (.9), the Locker (.7), and Pixie Corner (.8).  The last two make great beginner leads or TR's, as you can easily walk to the top of the cliff and set anchors and ropes, and/or walk off.
